newsitem.title: USA: Wayfarer to launch intranet 'push' technology.
newsitem.headline: Wayfarer to launch intranet 'push' technology.

text.p: Wayfarer Communications Inc said it will announce on Monday the commercial availability of new software that enables companies to customise information for delivery to employee's computers.
The product, to be called Incisa, allows managers to send information from both the public Internet and private networks known as intranets to groups of employees.

The company is taking a different tact than PointCast Networks, the startup that attracted a quick following in the spring of 1996 when it launched a screensaver that could be updated with news, information and interactive advertising.

Incisa utilizes a screensaver as well, but it is designed to bear a company's own brand name and to combine information from corporate databases with relevant information from suppliers like PC Quote and Reuters Holdings Plc, the international news and information organization.
Wayfarer says it can deliver selected information to a company's employees using "a fraction of the network bandwidth required by other such technologies."
Wayfarer said its software has been in beta testing at dozens of Fortune 1,000 companies.
These include NationsBank, Ralston-Purina Group, Sprint Corp, Amoco Corp, International Paper and Gannett Co's USA Today.
Mitch Hadley, a vice president at NationsBank Corp, said a key feature was the ability to use the software to filter out distracting, non-business content.
Wayfarer said the software enables two-way communication, contains multiple security levels and can be run generating one twenty-fifth the network traffic of other consumer webcasting products.

The Incisa server runs on Microsoft Corp's Windows NT, with a Sun Microsystems Inc Sun Solaris version due in March, and can work with desktops running Windows 95, Window NT and -- in March -- Windows 3.1.
Pricing starts at $5,000 for 100 seats with discounts available for higher-volume purchases.
Wayfarer is backed by Silicon Valley venture capital firms including Sequoia Capital, Hummer/Winblad Venture Partners and Bay Partnes, along with Robertson Stephens & Co., and Stanford University.
